results.notes:
Location is upper Morro Creek along Highway 41 West, between Morro Bay and Atascadero.
Habitat is riparian, with a dense canopy of live oak, California bay, sycamore and willow. The specific location is a deep shaded canyon.
Substrate is siliceous non-calcareous boulder situated at or just above the high flood line of the creek. Probably does not become inundated.

Thallus consists of greenish grey convex areoles, K+Y, C-, KC-. Apothecia black, with raised margin lacking algae, margin sometimes pruinose. Hymennium hyaline, hypothecium brown becoming bright brown to orange-brown in K, epihymenium very dark aeruginose, K-.

Spores simple, hyaline, ellipsoid. Average 14.1×7.2µm (13.7×8.0, 16.6×8.7, 14.7×8.4, 13.6×5.3, 12.0×5.7). Ascus stain not done.

results.notes:
Location is upper Morro Creek along Highway 41 West, between Morro Bay and Atascadero.

Habitat is riparian, with a dense canopy of live oak, California bay, sycamore and willow. The specific location is a deep shaded canyon.

Substrate is a siliceous non-calcareous boulder situated at or just above the high flood line of the creek. Probably does not become inundated.

Thallus yellow-green, with broad lobes that have a thin brown margin and small amounts of white crystalized pruina, roundish laminal pseudocyphellae, marginal soralia occasionally forming crescent-shaped form or under lobe tip, cortex K+Y. Underside black in center, pale brown under lobes, with sparse simple rhizines concolorous with lower cortex. Medulla white, C+pink. Apothecia absent, pycnidia not seen.

results.notes: Growing near Tsuga canadensis, Pinus strobus, Pinus subg. Pinus. Did not record any hardwoods in my field notes but Fagus grandifolia and Quercus spp. were in the wider area and their leaves were present at the collection site. 2 fruiting bodies growing scattered along a path. Collected older fruiting body with a Hypomyces infection in a small portion of the cap. Did not collect younger fruiting body. Pores bruising strongly blue-green and fading to dull green before brown. Stem tan with red dots and olive tints. Context white in cap and brownish in the stem. Cap context not staining except for faintly blue-green near the edges. Stem context staining dull blue-green. Odor indistinct. NH4OH yellow-brown on cap becoming greenish. 5% KOH yellow-brown on cap.
results.location_name: Hocking State Forest, Hocking Co., Ohio, USA

results.notes: Growing in a grassy clearing on a ridge-top near Quercus sect. Lobatae, Carya sp., Fagus grandifolia, Prunus serotina and Acer nigrum. Growing scattered and in clusters of up to 3 fruiting bodies joined at the base. Cap smooth and mottled with orange shades. Stem with whitish reticulation. Young pores white and stuffed, becoming yellow in age. Pores not bruising. Cap context white and with some reddish stains. Taste mild. Some fruiting bodies chewed and pulled out of the ground by rodents. NH4OH purple on cap, neutral to slightly purple on stem and purple to purplish brown on pores. 5% KOH red on cap and light brown on stem and pores. 10% FeSO4 neutral on cap and stem, neutral to grayish on pores.

results.notes:
On a cone scale of Pinus radiata in a native stand of Monterey Pine Forest.

Thallus not evident, or barely changing substrate color. Apothecia lecideine, black, plane, slightly raised margin, without pruina, 0.4-0.7mm. Hymenium seems inspersed, yellowish. Hypothecium darker. Epihymenium dark brown. Hymenium yellow in K, pale blue in K/I stain. Couldn’t get good ascus view, but seemed to be bitunicate.

Spores narrowly ellipsoid, hyaline, 3-septate, immature spores measured 13.8×3.4, 11.1×2.5, 11.0×2.7, 13.3×2.8.

This seems to go to the Rocellaceae family, something like Lecanactis salicina (spores are too big) or the Central California Coast endemic Bactrospora spiralis, although I did not see the spores breaking into parts as described for this species. More work to be done.
results.location_name: Fiscalini Preserve, Cambria, California, USA

results.notes: Growing in rich black soil and leaf litter in a seasonally flooded forest near Fagus grandifolia, Quercus bicolor, Carya sp. and Acer saccharum. Fruiting body 9.4 cm high. results.notes:
Macro.
====
AscocarpType: Compound
Ascocarp colour: Dirty mustard yellow, turning reddish brownish at edges.
Ascocarp size: Sexual cap = 48mm long x 36mm across; total length = 88mm
Ascocarp rim: Edges of alveoli reddish brown
Ascocarp shape: Conical with wide lacunae and narrow edges. Lacunae about 30, irregular, longer then wide, rectangular to elongated pentagonal or hexagonal, about 8-13mm wide and varying from 15-20 and up to 24mm in length in few lacunae. Edge narrow, 0.5mm wide

Stipe size: 45mm long x 20mm wide (25mm at the base)
Stipe colour: Pale apricot-orange
Stipe texture: Finely granulose
Flesh: Completely hollowed without cottony mycelia
Flesh colour: Greyish-beige

Additional notes Stipe base swollen, bulbous branching and dendroid

MICRO:
==

Paraphyses.
-————-
Paraphyses: Present, not frequent, septate, shorter from asci

Paraphyses shape (apex): Capitate, with a rounded, elliptic-rectangular or rarely irregaular-deltate head, (24.1-)30.7(-34.1) µm long
Paraphyses width: Column 6.8-9.5µm (mean 8.37µm) ; apical head (widest part): 12-17.8µm (mean 14.1µm)
Paraphyses length: Total length 142-174µm (mean = 161.4µm); Length of apical hypha 98-129µm (mean = 113.4µm)

Other remarks: Paraphyses dextrinoid in IKI, especially its head. They are 1- to 2- (3- septate), with the septa located at the basal third of the paraphyses.

Ascum
-—-
Shape: Cylindrical, straight or slightly sinusoidial-irregular, usually with a distinct kink at the base
No. of Spores: 8
Operculum Not: observed
Tunic (Wall): Uni-tunicate
Ascum length (range): 220 – 288 µm
Ascum length (mean): 262.7 µm
Ascum width (range): 15.2 – 20.8 µm
Ascum width (mean): 17.7 µm
Ascum L:W ratio: 15
Iodine reaction (J +/J -): J-ve but dextrinoid
Orifice: Absent
Remarks: Sometimes spore are clustered at the top of the ascum making it to swell nad bulge

AscoSpores
-————
Spore length (range): 20.26 – 24.9 µm
Spore length (mean): 22.7 µm
Spore width (range): 9.97 – 15.9 µm
Spore width (mean): 12.4 µm
Spore Q factor (range): 1.54 – 2.24 µm
Spore Q factor (mean): 1.84
Spore shape: Fusoid-elliptical, widest at the centre with two identical rounded poles
Spore septa: Aseptate
Spore surface: Finely course or rugolose
Oil bodies: Absent

Arrangement of spores: Spores arranged obliquely, sometimes aggregated at the upper part of the ascum.

Others:
-——
Excipulum (medullary): Profusely branched, intricate and reticulate hypha forming a textura intricata, with hyphal elements 3-6um wide and 24-45um long, but very variable in size and shape (variably and irregularly bent, curved or kinked)

results.notes:
The large specimen was weird. I would’ve thought it would be expanded by the time it got so large and heavy; the gills are obscenely exposed from above; ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶i̶t̶ ̶l̶o̶o̶k̶s̶ ̶l̶i̶k̶e̶ ̶i̶t̶ ̶h̶a̶s̶ ̶A̶g̶a̶r̶i̶c̶a̶c̶e̶a̶e̶-̶s̶t̶y̶l̶e̶ ̶p̶i̶g̶m̶e̶n̶t̶e̶d̶ ̶p̶a̶t̶c̶h̶e̶s̶ I am an idiot – recently it was pointed out that the “background” of the “scales” is just large areas where the cap covering was eaten by something. I believe it’s the only fresh-looking mushroom I’ve ever collected that grew mold overnight (pictured). Real wacky.
The small specimen erupted overnight, exposing its gills (pictured). I thought only Amanita did that. Is it a coincidence that both genera are volvate?

results.notes: I was not able to take photos of these in the field but took (admittedly very rough) drawings in the field. Growing ~2400 m above sea level in grass in a forest clearing near Picea sp. (P. pungens or P. engelmannii), Abies sp. (A. lasiocarpa or A. concolor), Populus tremuloides and Ameliancher alnifolia. Single fruiting body found possibly immature. Fruiting body 4 cm high. Cap 2.7 cm wide, olive-brown with darker brown spots and with an inrolled margin. Pores small, yellow and not bruising. Stem apex a brighter yellow than the pores. Area of stem below apex also yellow but covered with orange pruina. Area below that purplish red. Base of stem dirty brown with white basal mycelium. Context pale yellow in the cap and top half of the stem. Area of context below this dark red. Context in base of stem brown, becoming paler toward the very base. Slow, weak blue bruising in near the base of the yellow zone of the context. Taste sweet. Odor indistinct.

results.notes:
Habitat: Artificial mulch under Nerium and Cypress trees (embelishment)
Habitat notes: Roadside embelishment
Remarks: Numerous solitary specimens in small groups

Macro Characters
=====
Morphological type: Agaric, Psathyrelloid
Hymenium: Lamellae
Length: 57 – 71mm (mean: 66.5mm)
Umbo: Shallow and indistinct
Ring (Veil): No
Cup (Volva): No
Texture / feel: Smooth, dry, ribs minutely felt-like or velvetly
Smell: Indistinct
Taste: Not tested
Spore print: Blackish brown
Stipe/flesh bruising: No reaction
Stipe/flesh exudate: Nil

Pileus
Cap diameter: 20 – 34mm (mean: 25.7mm)
Cap colour: Beige with pale grey colour at cap’s radial furrows
Cap shape: Initially hemispherical then open to broadly convex – applanate
Cap margin: rather regular, furrowed
Cap texture: Minutely velutinous or felt-like (under magnification glass)
Cap ornamentation: nil

Cap additional notes: Cap distinctly and deeply furrowed radially, sometimes splitting along the furrows. Furrows pale gray, different from the beige colour of the pileus surface.

Stipe
Stipe length: 55 – 67mm (mean: 62.8mm)
Stipe diameter: 2 – 3mm (mean: 2.7mm)
Stipe colour : Whitish-beige, sometimes hue becomes more intense to an amber-ochre colour at a portion along its central part
Stipe flesh: Fistulose, cream or white
Stipe shape: Cylindrical, slightly arcuate
Stipe cross-section: Terete, hollowed
Stipe texture: Smooth
Stipe strength: Very fragile, breaks easily and splits longitudinally into out-curved ribs.

Hymenium (Lamellae)
Lamella width: 3 – 4mm (mean: 3.7mm)
Lamella attachment: Free or less often shortly adnexed
Lamella colour: Mouse grey with beige tones covered with black deposit of spores
Lamella edge colour: Concolorous or slightly darker, but often appears with a black margin of spore deposit.
Lamella edge margin type: Smooth
Lamella edge profile shape: Straight to minutely convex at the ends
Lamella spacing / density: Moderate, not very crowded.
Lamellulae: Few or absent
Intervenose: No

MICRO Characters

Basidia: Difficult to spot because they deliquesce rapidly, and practically absent in old or exsiccat specimens.

Basidiospores: Tetrasporous
Basidia shape: Clavate, with a rectangular-rhombic head which tapers to a stipe-like base from its lower half. length c. 25-30um. Sterigmata very small and indistinct.

Cystidia
Pleurocystidia (gill faces): Few observed and doubtful, broadly utriform, smooth.
Pleurocystidia size: about 50-58 × 24-28 µm (only three oserved)

Cheilocystidia (gill edges): Several cystidia at the gill edge, small, broadly capitate to broadly cylindrical.
Cheilocystidium ornamentation: Smooth
Cheilocystidium length: range 19.8 – 41 µm
Cheilocystidium length: mean 25.22 µm
Cheilocystidium width: range 10.6 – 20 µm
Cheilocystidium width: mean 12.72 µm

Spore
Spore print: Blackish brown
Spore length: range 11.1 – 14.5 µm
Spore length: mean 12.9 µm
Spore width: range 6.3 – 8.1 µm
Spore width: mean 7.3 µm
Spore Q factor: range 1.5 – 2
Spore Q factor: mean 1.8
Spore shape: Ovate-elliptical, widest about 1/3 its length
Oil bodies: Not observed
Amyloid reaction: Inamyloid
Spore surface: Smooth
Apiculum: Tiny, slightly eccentrical
Germinal pore: Located at the narrowest pole, central, distinct

Misc.
Pileipellis type: Hymenoderme of sphaeropedunculate hyphae with short, brownish stipes, c. 50um x 25um wide, homogenous in shape. Brownish setae about 400um with a bulbouse, semi-ovoid base were observed in young specimens.

Veil: Not observed
Caulocystidia: Not examined
Radicles/rhizoids at stipe base: White mycelium
Clamp junctions: Not observed

results.notes: This mushroom is small has white very slightly decurrent gills. Appears to bruise slightly yellow on cap and stem.Cap is about one inch .stem is fiberous and about two inches. The really outstanding feature is that this mushroom smells STRONGLY of gardenias. So much so that if you were blindfolded you could not tell the difference between the two. results.notes:
Growing at the base of a large, urban oak tree that lacked obvious symptoms of disease. Soil rocky and compacted (in an unpaved alleyway). Entire specimen about 30 cm across and 20 cm high. Fronds up to 5 cm broad. Odor fresh, moist and earthy but not distinct. Some pores present but ragged and hard to discern as most have deteriorated or been eaten by slugs. Pores less than 1mm across and shallow. Flesh concolorous with caps, marbled showing waves of growth. Fleshy, not tough.

Unfortunately the specimen was in poor condition, but I felt that the novelty of encountering a mushroom like this in a west coast city warranted it worthwhile to post.

I HAVE SINCE OBSERVED THIS MUSHROOM FROM THE SAME TREE IN OCTOBER OF 2017 AND 2018 IN PRIME CONDITION, AND IT IS CONFIRMED TO BE Grifola frondosa. IT IS VOUCHERED IN THE UBC HERBARIUM, SUMBITTED BY PAUL KROEGER***

Habitat: Artificial mulch under Nerium and Cypress trees (embelishment)

Remarks: Numerous solitary specimens in small groups

Macro Characters
===
Main characters
Morphological type: Agaric, Conocyboid?
Hymenium: Lamellae
Length: 42 – 42mm (mean: 42mm)
Umbo: Small and shallow, darker from rest of cap
Ring: No
Volva: No
Overall texture of the pileus: Smooth, becoming wrinkled with age
Smell: Indistinct
Taste: Not tested
Spore print: Ochre to pale tobacco brown
Stipe/flesh bruising: No reaction
Stipe/flesh exudate: Not tested
Character 1
Character 2
Further observations

Pileus
Cap diameter: 16 – 16mm (mean: 16mm)
Cap colour: Tobacco amber-brown with a darker centre and paler radial striations at the terminal half
Cap shape: Convex then applanate with upturned margins
Cap margin: Regular, minutely furrowed and subcrenulate at the edge
Cap texture : Smooth, minutely rugulose with age
Cap ornamentation: Smooth, unornamented
Cap additional notes: Slightly hygrophanous

Stipe
Stipe length: 38 – 38mm (mean: 38mm)
Stipe diameter: 2 – 2mm (mean: 2mm)
Stipe colour : Ochre becominb browner towards the base
Stipe flesh: Fistulose, cream to pale buff
Stipe shape: Cylindrical, slightly arcuate at the base
Stipe cross-section: Terete, hollowed
Stipe texture: Pruinose or minutely-floccose tufts
Stipe strength: Tough, elastic

Hymenium (Lamellae)
Lamella width: 2 – 2mm (mean: 2mm)
Lamella attachment: Narrowly adnexed (almost free)
Lamella colour: Tobacco brown, homogenous
Lamella edge colour: Beige or slightly lighter from the lamella face
Lamella edge margin: Flocculose
Lamella edge profile shape: Shallow convex
Lamella spacing / density: Moderately crowded
Lamellulae: Few or absent
Intervenose: No

Micro Characters
====
Basidia
Basidiospores: (2-)4
Basidium length: range 20 – 21.25 µm
Basidium length: mean 20.6 µm
Basidium width: range 7 – 8 µm
Basidium width: mean 7.4 µm
Sterigmata length: 1.9 µm
Shape: Clavate, widest below the apex, head rounded-ovate then rectangular below
Remarks: Sterigmata very slender and short, often inconspicuous

Cystidia
Pleurocystidia (gill faces): Absent or not observed
Pleurocystidia size: n/a
Pleurocystidia other notes: n/a
Cheilocystidia (gill edges): Numerous in clusters, stout, broadly clavate to capitate with a large rounded head.
Cheilocystidium ornamentation: Smooth
Cheilocystidium length: range 21.35 – 34 µm
Cheilocystidium length: mean 26.44 µm
Cheilocystidium width: range 8 – 14.8 µm
Cheilocystidium width: mean 12.07 µm

Spore
Spore print: Ochre to pale tobacco brown
Spore length range: 6.7 – 9.4 µm
Spore length mean: 8.2 µm
Spore width range: 4.5 – 5.6 µm
Spore width mean: 5.1 µm
Spore Q factor range: 1.3 – 1.9
Spore Q factor mean: 1.6
Spore shape: Elliptical
Oil bodies: Single central oil body sometimes accompanied by another 1-2 smaller oil bodies
Amyloid reaction: Inamyloid
Spore surface: Smooth
Apiculum: Slightly eccentric and bent sideways (oblique orientation)
Germinal pore: Tiny, central

Misc.
Pileipellis type: Hymenoderme of pyriform hyphae 20-30um wide with a wide short peduncle.
Veil: Absent
Caulocystidia / hair: Not examined
Radicles/rhizoids at stipe base: White, not conspicuous
Clamp junctions: Very few observed

Reactions
==
KOH: No reaction

Chicago, Illinois, USA

results.notes:
Lactarius deliciosus (L.) Gray, Russulaceae, Agaricales.
Local name: Рыжик настоящий, рыжик обыкновенный.
Orange zoned cap: 6-12cm wide, broadly convex up to flattened and shallow sunken in the centre; margins curved in, smooth, colour from light orange or bright-orange with several or many zones up to dull light yellow-orange with dying; old one sometimes becoming funnel-shaped. Any damage makes bright-orange spots turning into bluish-green. Odour is fragrant. Flesh is pinkish-white up to light orange.
Gills: attached up to slightly descending, close, narrow and sharp-edged; colour from light-orange-yellow up to bright-orange. Stalk: 1.5-4cm long, pinkish-white with orange outer rim (cross-cutting); 1.5-2.5cm thick, central, sometimes narrowing down, hollow with edging. Young unit has weak orange milk.
Habitat: well-known and very common kind, scattered small groups up to abundant in pine-tree forest.
Edibility: delicious (many methods of cooking).
June -September.

I had seen them growing upright in the mulch the night before, but it was too dark to take pictures of them. results.notes: The specimen was large and the cap was dark and wrinkled enough that I thought it was in the esculenta gr. when I first collected it, but Else pointed out the 3-lobed nature of the cap and the attachment to wood were more consistent with infula. The spores and the paraphyses were consistent with her ID. It had well developed rhizomorphs at the base. It would not be surprising if it turns out to be something that is in the infula groupt, but distinct from the European species.

results.notes:
Growing near Live Oak and Fir.
Caps up to 5.6 cm across.
Cuticle peeled about 25% of cap width.
Gills very white and rather soft.
Taste acrid.
Spore print white.
Spores ~ 6.9-9.0 X 5.9-8.0 microns, mostly subglobose(Qavg. = 1.13), and with few warts and many fine lines forming a reticulum.
Looks something like R. cremoricolor but spores seem different and overall, these seem smaller and more delicate.

results.notes:
Although I assumed that my illustration was pretty close to life-sized, I didn’t note that on the page. I do recall them being smaller than “normal” for our more familiar Sierran “albolutescens,” and Fred Stevens remarking at the time that he thought it was an unnamed species that had been seen before, and was recently published as A. stevensii. This took place at Desjardin’s SFSU Sierran Field Mushroom Class in 2005.

The fact of the pink gills when young as well as that bright chrome yellow cap with handling and its overall small size (altho maybe not smaller than 38 mm!) are making me lean towards stevensii vs moronii (new name for albolutescens).

R we confused yet??! Fred might have saved it, but I didn’t.

results.notes:
Gregory clitocybe key:
Not arising from fungal mass, without rhizomorphs at base, without purplish tints at any age. Pileus orange, fading to white. Lamellar not browning in age, no odor. Pileus hygrophanous, mushroom not with melting snow. Small, with thin stipe. Faintly striated. Under pines in mixed woods.
This comes out as either coniferophila or a mild fragrans.

results.notes:
Found on a woodland walk after some weeks of steady rain near Los Angeles, growing in mixed oak/other fallen leaves about 20 feet from the base of some live oaks.

The color is a light orange/tan with older specimens appearing whiter. The stem is hollow and there is no bulbous base. There is no veil that I can see on any of the mushrooms I looked at. I do not smell anything distinctive about these mushrooms.

Some of the mushrooms were growing in small clumps, some were growing solo.

Could be a clitocybe?

Any help in ID’ing these would be most appreciated.
